clinical_study.brief_title: Obstructive Sleep Apnoea and Adipose Tissue Dysfunction
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of Hypoxia in Adipose Tissue of Subjects With Obstructive Sleep Apnoea

lead_sponsor.agency: Royal Devon and Exeter NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: Royal Devon and Exeter NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: Dysfunctional adipose tissue predisposes to cardiovascular disease. Similarly, the risk of cardiovascular disease appears to be increased in subjects with obstructive sleep apnoea. Reduced adipose tissue oxygen availability has been described in obesity and may also be a mechanism in obstructive sleep apnoea. Hypoxia induces inflammation and fibrosis in adipose tissue which are factors contributing to cardiovascular risk. The investigators hypothesize that adipose tissue's oxygen uptake is reduced in subjects with obstructive sleep apnoea by comparing in vivo AT oxygenation and blood flow in tissue of control subjects.

detailed_description.textblock: Assessment includes a adipose tissue biopsy and measurement of oxygenation and blood flow by a Clarke type electrodes and non-invasive Doppler techniques.

primary_outcome.measure: pO2 in adipose tissue by Clarke type electrode
primary_outcome.description: Measurement of pO2 by Clarke type electrode

secondary_outcome.measure: blood flow in adipose tissue by laser Doppler techniques
secondary_outcome.description: assessment of tissue blood flow by laser Doppler techniques

other_outcome.measure: adipose tissue gene expression of HIF-1alpha
other_outcome.description: adipose tissue expression of hypoxia related genes

arm_group.description: subjects with no obstructive sleep apnoea

study_pop.textblock: Subjects with newly diagnosed obstructive sleep apnoea and controls

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- men with or without obstructive sleep apnoea
Exclusion Criteria:
- weight loss interventions
- steroid use
- active smoking
